title: 5-4-3-2-1 Grounding Technique
content: When feeling anxious or overwhelmed, use this grounding technique: Name 5 things you can see, 4 things you can touch, 3 things you can hear, 2 things you can smell, and 1 thing you can taste. This helps bring your attention to the present moment and reduces anxiety symptoms.

title: Thought Record Worksheet
content: When you notice a strong emotion, complete this thought record: 1) Describe the situation objectively, 2) Identify your automatic thoughts, 3) Rate your emotions and their intensity (0-10), 4) List evidence for and against the thought, 5) Develop a more balanced thought, 6) Re-rate your emotional intensity. This helps identify and challenge negative thinking patterns.

title: Progressive Muscle Relaxation
content: Systematically tense and then relax each muscle group in your body, starting with your toes and working up to your head. Hold the tension for 5-7 seconds, then release completely and notice the contrast between tension and relaxation. This helps reduce physical symptoms of anxiety and promotes overall relaxation.

title: Activity Scheduling and Monitoring
content: Plan and schedule enjoyable and meaningful activities throughout your week. Include: 1) Pleasant activities (things you enjoy), 2) Mastery activities (things that give you a sense of accomplishment), 3) Social activities, 4) Self-care activities. Rate your mood before and after each activity (0-10) to identify patterns and effective mood boosters.

title: 4-7-8 Breathing Exercise
content: Practice this calming breathing technique: Breathe in through your nose for 4 counts, hold your breath for 7 counts, breathe out through your mouth for 8 counts. Repeat 4 cycles. The extended exhale activates your parasympathetic nervous system, promoting relaxation and reducing anxiety.

title: Values Clarification Exercise
content: Identify your core values by reflecting on: What matters most to you in life? What kind of person do you want to be? What would you want people to remember about you? Write down your top 5-7 values and consider how your current actions and decisions align with these values. Use this as a guide for making meaningful life choices.

title: Behavioral Experiment Planning
content: Test negative predictions through planned experiments: 1) Identify your specific prediction and rate belief (0-100%), 2) Design a safe, gradual experiment to test it, 3) Predict what you think will happen, 4) Conduct the experiment, 5) Record what actually happened, 6) Compare results to your prediction, 7) Re-rate your belief in the original prediction. This helps challenge catastrophic thinking.

title: Three Good Things Journal
content: Each evening, write down three things that went well during the day and explain why you think each positive event occurred. Focus on your role in making good things happen. This practice helps shift attention from negative to positive experiences and builds optimism over time.

title: Mindful Body Scan
content: Lie down comfortably and slowly move your attention through each part of your body, starting from your toes and moving up to the top of your head. Notice any sensations, tension, or feelings without trying to change them. Simply observe with curious, non-judgmental awareness. This practice increases body awareness and promotes relaxation.

title: Problem-Solving Worksheet
content: Use this systematic approach for difficult problems: 1) Define the problem clearly and specifically, 2) Brainstorm all possible solutions (don't evaluate yet), 3) List pros and cons for each solution, 4) Choose the most promising solution, 5) Break it into specific action steps, 6) Implement the plan, 7) Evaluate the results and adjust as needed.

title: Worry Time Technique
content: Schedule a specific 15-20 minute 'worry time' each day. When worrying thoughts arise throughout the day, write them down and postpone them to your designated worry time. During worry time, review your list and spend time on each worry: categorize as 'actionable' or 'not actionable.' For actionable worries, make a plan. For non-actionable ones, practice acceptance.

title: Self-Compassion Break
content: When experiencing difficult emotions or self-criticism, pause and: 1) Acknowledge your suffering ('This is a moment of difficulty'), 2) Recognize common humanity ('Difficulty is part of life, I'm not alone'), 3) Offer yourself kindness ('May I be kind to myself in this moment'). Place your hand on your heart as a gesture of self-care.

title: Thought Defusion Techniques
content: Create distance from difficult thoughts using these techniques: 1) 'I'm having the thought that...' (preface thoughts with this phrase), 2) Thank your mind ('Thanks mind, for that thought'), 3) Sing the thought to a silly tune, 4) Visualize the thought as leaves floating down a stream. The goal isn't to eliminate thoughts but to reduce their impact on your behavior.

title: Pleasant Activity Planning
content: Create a personalized list of pleasant activities across different categories: 1) Physical activities (walking, dancing, sports), 2) Social activities (calling friends, group activities), 3) Creative activities (art, music, writing), 4) Relaxation activities (baths, reading, nature), 5) Achievement activities (organizing, learning). Schedule at least one pleasant activity daily.

title: Cognitive Reframing Practice
content: When faced with negative thoughts, practice reframing: 1) Identify the negative thought, 2) Ask 'What thinking error might this be?' (catastrophizing, all-or-nothing, mind reading, etc.), 3) Ask 'What would I tell a good friend in this situation?', 4) Consider alternative, more balanced perspectives, 5) Generate a more realistic, helpful thought.

title: Panic Attack Coping Plan
content: When experiencing panic symptoms: 1) Remind yourself 'This is anxiety, not danger', 2) Use slow, deep breathing (in for 4, hold for 4, out for 6), 3) Name 5 things you can see, 4 you can hear, 3 you can touch, 4) Use positive self-talk ('This will pass', 'I can handle this'), 5) Stay where you are if safe, don't flee, 6) Use progressive muscle relaxation if possible.

title: Daily Mood Tracking
content: Track your mood daily using a simple 1-10 scale where 1 = very depressed/anxious and 10 = excellent mood. Also note: 1) What you did that day, 2) Sleep quality (1-10), 3) Stress level (1-10), 4) One thing you're grateful for. Look for patterns between activities, sleep, stress, and mood over time.

title: Social Anxiety Exposure Ladder
content: Create a hierarchy of social situations from least to most anxiety-provoking (0-100 anxiety rating). Start with situations rated 20-30 and gradually work up. For each step: 1) Practice the situation repeatedly until anxiety decreases by 50%, 2) Use coping strategies (breathing, positive self-talk), 3) Record what happened vs. what you feared, 4) Move to the next step when ready.

title: Sleep Hygiene Checklist
content: Improve sleep quality with these practices: 1) Keep consistent sleep/wake times, 2) Create a relaxing bedtime routine, 3) Keep bedroom cool, dark, and quiet, 4) Avoid screens 1 hour before bed, 5) No caffeine after 2 PM, 6) No large meals 3 hours before bed, 7) Use bed only for sleep and intimacy, 8) If you can't fall asleep in 20 minutes, get up and do a quiet activity.

title: Assertiveness Training Techniques
content: Practice assertive communication using the DESC technique: 1) Describe the situation objectively, 2) Express your feelings using 'I' statements, 3) Specify what you want to happen, 4) Consequences - explain positive outcomes of compliance or negative outcomes of non-compliance. Practice with low-stakes situations first, maintaining calm tone and respectful body language.

title: Distress Tolerance Skills
content: When in crisis, use the TIPP technique to quickly change your body chemistry: 1) Temperature - use cold water on face/hands or hold ice cubes, 2) Intense exercise - do jumping jacks, run in place for 5-10 minutes, 3) Paced breathing - slow, deep breaths, 4) Paired muscle relaxation - tense and release muscle groups. These techniques help when emotions feel overwhelming.

title: Mindful Eating Exercise
content: Practice mindful eating with a small food item (raisin, piece of chocolate): 1) Observe its appearance, texture, smell, 2) Notice thoughts and feelings that arise, 3) Eat very slowly, paying attention to taste, texture, temperature, 4) Notice the urge to eat quickly and resist it, 5) Observe how your body feels before, during, and after eating. This develops mindful awareness and can help with emotional eating.

title: Grief and Loss Processing
content: When dealing with loss, use this structured approach: 1) Allow yourself to feel the emotions without judgment, 2) Create a memory book or ritual to honor what/who you've lost, 3) Identify what the loss means to you and your life, 4) Reach out for support from others, 5) Gradually re-engage with meaningful activities, 6) Consider how your experience might help others. Grief is individual and non-linear.

title: Mindfulness of Thoughts Exercise
content: Sit comfortably and observe your thoughts for 10 minutes: 1) Notice when thoughts arise without getting caught up in their content, 2) Label them simply as 'thinking' and return attention to your breath, 3) Observe thoughts like clouds passing in the sky - they come and go naturally, 4) Don't judge thoughts as good or bad, just notice them, 5) If you get caught up in a thought, gently return to observing.

title: Interpersonal Effectiveness Skills
content: Improve relationships using the DEAR MAN technique for requests: 1) Describe the situation, 2) Express feelings, 3) Assert your needs clearly, 4) Reinforce benefits of saying yes, 5) Mindful - stay focused on your goal, 6) Appear confident with body language and tone, 7) Negotiate when possible. Practice this skill in low-stakes situations first.

title: Relapse Prevention Planning
content: Create a comprehensive relapse prevention plan: 1) Identify your personal warning signs and triggers, 2) List coping strategies that have worked before, 3) Identify supportive people you can contact, 4) Plan changes to your environment or routine, 5) Include professional support contacts, 6) Write a letter to yourself for motivation during difficult times, 7) Review and update your plan regularly.

title: Emotion Regulation Strategies
content: When experiencing intense emotions, use the PLEASE skills: 1) Treat PhysicaL illness - take care of your body, 2) Balance Eating - don't eat too much or too little, 3) Avoid mood-Altering substances, 4) Balance Sleep - aim for 7-9 hours, 5) Get Exercise - even light movement helps. These basic self-care practices create a foundation for emotional stability.

title: Behavioral Chain Analysis
content: Analyze problematic behaviors to understand and prevent them: 1) Identify the specific problem behavior, 2) Describe the prompting event that started the chain, 3) Identify your vulnerability factors that day, 4) List each link in the chain (thoughts, feelings, actions), 5) Identify consequences of the behavior, 6) Find points where you could have used skills, 7) Make a plan for prevention.

title: Loving-Kindness Meditation
content: Practice sending loving-kindness to yourself and others: 1) Start with yourself: 'May I be happy, may I be healthy, may I be at peace', 2) Extend to a loved one with the same phrases, 3) Include a neutral person (someone you neither like nor dislike), 4) Include a difficult person, 5) Extend to all beings everywhere. Notice any resistance and practice anyway. This builds compassion and reduces negative emotions.

title: Cognitive Defusion Exercises
content: Practice these exercises to reduce the impact of difficult thoughts: 1) 'Leaves on a Stream' - visualize thoughts as leaves floating away on water, 2) 'Observer Self' - step back and observe your thoughts from a neutral perspective, 3) 'Thoughts as Clouds' - watch thoughts pass like clouds in the sky, 4) Label thoughts by category ('worry thought', 'self-criticism', etc.). The goal is psychological flexibility, not thought elimination.
